choices.text: The incidence of heterotropic pregnancy is increasing
Atypical sites of ectopic are increasing due to IVF
The incidence of an ectopic increases by about 50% following a history of ectopic
The relative incidence of ectopic pregnancy is increased with the use of intrauterine devices.

questions.text: All are correct regarding ectopic pregnancy except:
questions.solution:
Ans: C. The incidence of an ectopic increases by about 50% following a history of ectopic

 

Risk Factors

    • h/o Tubal Surgery (e.g., for fertility restoration or sterilization): HIGHEST RISK
    • Prior h/o salpingitis: 6 – 10-fold increased risk
    • h/o previous ectopic: 5-fold risk (10 – 15% chance of repeat ectopic)
    • Peri tubal adhesions (like endometriosis)
    • Salpingitis isthmica nodosa
    • Congenital tubal anomalies
    • Infertility (ART)
      • Associated with Atypical implantations and heterotopic pregnancies
      • Heterotopic pregnancies and heterotopic pregnancies are increasing due to this
    • Contraception: Relative numbers increased with intra-uterine devices (Absolute numbers decreased)

 

Ref: Page 371, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: βhCG levels > 100,000
Plateau in βhCG levels
Theca lutein cyst > 6 cm
Younger maternal age

questions.text: All are risk factors for progression of Hydatidiform mole to gestational trophoblastic neoplasia except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Younger maternal age

 

Older maternal age is a risk factor for progress to GTN

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Risk Factors for progress to GTN

 

  1. Complete mole (15%) > Partial mole (5%)

  2. Older Maternal Age

  3. βhCG levels > 100,000

  4. Uterine size large for gestational age

  5. Theca lutein cysts > 6 cm

  6. Slow decline in βhCG levels

 

Ref: page no 393, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 69 XXY
69XXX
46XX
45XO

questions.text: Karyotype of a complete mole is:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 46XX

A Complete mole is ALWAYS DIPLOID (46XX or 46XY)

Hence other Options are excluded

Educational Objective: 

  • Partial moles are always TRIPLOID (69XXX or 69XXY)
    • They are formed when 2 sperms fertilize one ova
    • The paternal contribution is called diandry
    • Hence both maternal and paternal component are found
    • Usually, 69XXX or 69XXY
  • Complete moles are DIPLOID
    • Formed by either 1 sperm fertilizing an empty/ inactivated ovum and then undergoes duplication – this is called androgenesis

OR

  • 2 sperms (dispermy) fertilize an empty/ inactivated ovum
  • 46XX or 46 XY
  • Only paternal component; No maternal component

 

Ref: page no. 389 William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Complete mole
Fibroid uterus with pregnancy
Multiple pregnancy
Polyhydramnios

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of 3 months pregnancy with vaginal bleeding. On examination, the uterus corresponds to the size of a 20 week uterus. An ultrasound shows the following picture. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Complete mole

  • This image shows the typical ‘Snowstorm appearance’ which is characteristically seen in complete molar pregnancy
  • Another clue given in the question is the size of the uterus is 20 weeks in a 3 month pregnancy (> Period of gestation)

Other Options: 

  • Option B: Fibroid uterus with pregnancy: The fetus will be seen alongwith a well circumscribed lesion in the uterus
  • Option C: Multiple pregnancy: 2 or more fetuses will be seen in the ultrasound
  • Option D: Increased amniotic fluid (which appears black on ultrasound)

Educational Objective: 

This image of an ultrasound image showing snowstoem

 

Ref: page no. 391, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Mifepristone + Misoprostol
Conservative management
Suction & Evacuation
Hysterotomy

questions.text: A 36-year-old woman presents to the OPD with complaints of 3 months pregnancy with vaginal bleeding. On examination, the uterus is palpable. An ultrasound shows the following picture. What is the best management option?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Suction & Evacuation

  • This image shows the typical ‘Snowstorm appearance’
  • This seen in complete molar pregnancy
  • The treatment of a molar pregnancy is suction evacuation followed by beta hCG surveillance

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Mifepristone and misoprostol is recommended for 1st trimester MTPs or missed abortions but not for molar pregnancy
  • Option B: Conservative management will not help as the molar tissue has to be evacuated
  • Option D: Hysterotomy is NOT indicated for a molar pregnancy, even for larger gestational ages, a suction evacuation is done

Educational Objective: 

Treatment of a molar pregnancy is suction and evacuation followed by beta hCG surveilance

 

Ref: Page no. 391, 392 William’s Obstetrics, 25th edition

choices.text: Partial mole
Complete mole
Down syndrome
Turner Syndrome

questions.text: Paternal chromosomal duplication is seen in?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Complete mole

Paternal chromosomal duplication is seen in COMPLETE mole

Educational Objective: 

  • Partial moles are always TRIPLOID
    • 2 sperm fertilize one ova
    • The paternal contribution is called diandry
    • Hence both maternal and paternal component present
    • Usually, 69XXX or 69XXY
  • Complete moles are DIPLOID
    • Formed by either 1 sperm fertilizing an empty/ inactivated ovum and then undergoes duplication – this is called androgenesis.
  • 2 sperms (dispermy) fertilize an empty/ inactivated ovum.
  • 46 XX or 46 XY
  • Only paternal component
  • No maternal component

 

Ref: Page no 389, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Incidence of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia is higher following a partial mole.
Serial measurement of βhCG is done to detect persistent trophoblastic proliferation.
Initial  baseline serum βhCG measurement is taken 48h post evacuation
βhCG is done weekly till negative then monthly till 6 months

questions.text: All are true regarding post evacuation surveillance of a Hydatidiform mole except?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Incidence of gestational trophoblastic neoplasia is higher following a partial mole

Let's Discuss all the Options: 

  • Option A: Incidence of gestational trophoblastic neoplasias is higher following a complete mole (15%) and not a partial mole (5%)
  • Option B: Serial measurement of βhCG is done to detect persistent trophoblastic proliferation.
  • Option C: Initial  baseline serum βhCG measurement is taken 48h post evacuation: This is a correct statement; following the 48h post evacuation sample, samples are then done weekly till the beta hCG touches zero and then monthly for 6 months
  • Option D: βhCG is done weekly till negative then monthly till 6 months. This is also a correct statement

Educational Objective:

Post Evacuation Surveillance of molar pregnancy

  • Risk of progression to GTN is higher following complete mole (!5%) than partial mole (5%)
  • Done by serial measurement of β hCG to detect persistent/ renewed trophoblastic proliferation.
  • 2 days post evacuation – Baseline
  • Then weekly till negative (7 weeks for partial; 9 weeks for complete)
  • Then monthly for 6 months
  • Contraception

 

Ref: Page no 393, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 6 weeks
7 weeks
8 weeks
9 weeks

questions.text: During post evacuation surveillance following evacuation of a complete mole, the median time for resolution of serum βhCG values is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 9 weeks

The median time for resolution of serum βhCG values is

  • 7 weeks for partial mole
  • 9 weeks for complete mole

 

Ref: page no 393, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

questions.text: A 22-year-old G2A1 presents at 10 weeks with mild abdominal pain This is her first antenatal visit. An ultrasound done showed bilateral enlarged ovaries as in the image. What would be the possible intrauterine finding?
questions.solution:
Ans. A.

  • The image shown is of an enlarged ovary with a typical appearance of theca lutein cysts. Theca lutein cysts are commonly associated with complete molar pregnancy. The ultrasound image showing a complete mole is A (Snowstorm appearance)

Other Options: 

  • B shows an intrauterine fetus
  • C shows an intrauterine gestational sac
  • D shows a normal non pregnant uterus

Educational Objective: 

Thecal lutein ovarian cysts (usually bilateral) are associated with molar pregnancy (especially complete mole

 

Ref: page no 393, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 1-5%
5-10%
10-15%
15-20%

questions.text: A 23y woman has a suction evacuation for molar pregnancy. The HPE is reported as a partial mole. You counsel her that her risk of progression to gestational trophoblastic neoplasia is?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-5%

Educational Objective: 

  • Risk of progress of complete mole to GTN: 15-20 %
  • Risk of progress of partial mole to GTN: 1-5%

 

Ref: Page 393, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Karyotype in partial mole is triploid
Theca lutein cysts are common in complete mole
There is evidence of some fetal tissue in a complete mole
There diffuse trophoblastic hyperplasia in a complete mole

questions.text: All are true regarding hydatidiform moles except?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. There is evidence of some fetal tissue in a complete mole.

Let's discuss all the options: 

  • Option A: Karyotype in partial mole is triploid: This is true. All partial moles are triplod
  • Option B: Theca lutein cysts are common in complete mole: This is also common in complete mole due to high beta hCG levels
  • Option C: There is evidence of some fetal tissue in a complete mole. This is false as fetal tissue is not seen in a complete mole. Fetal tissue is seen in a partial mole
  • Option D: There diffuse trophoblastic hyperplasia in a complete mole: This is also correct

Educational Objective:

Ref: Page no 390, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Hydatidiform mole
Choriocarcinoma
Ectopic Pregnancy
Abortion

questions.text: Q. A pregnant female has been presented with spotting P/V. on examination BP-110/70, pulse is 100 bpm. The USG picture is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Hydatidiform mole

  • This image shows the typical ‘Snowstorm appearance’
  • It is seen in complete molar pregnancy
  • Treatment of molar pregnancy is suction evacuation followed by βhCG surveillance

Educational Objective: 

This is the image of a snowstorm appearance which is seen in a complete molar pregnancy

Ref: page 392, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Complete abortion
Ectopic pregnancy
Incomplete abortion
Molar pregnancy

questions.text: A 34 year old woman presents to emergency with a complaint of 2 months of amenorrhea with bleeding associated with passage of grape-like clear vesicles. The likely diagnosis is :
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Molar pregnancy

  • The typical picture of amenorrhoea with bleeding with passage of "grape like vesicles" is seen in complete molar pregnancy

Other Options

  • Option A: Complete abortion: There would be a history of  amenorrhoea with pain and bleeding with passage of a tissue/ fleshy mass
  • Option B: Ectopic pregnancy: Presents as the classic triad of abdominal pain, bleeding and amenorrhoea
  • Option C: Incomplete abortion: This also presents as pain with bleeding and amenorrhoea. On examination, the cervical os is open

Educational Objective: 

Grossly, complete moles have abnormal chorionic villi that appear as a mass of grape like clear vesicles. These vary in size and often hang in clusters from thin pedicles.

 

Ref : Williams obstetrics, 26th edition, chapter 13

choices.text: Ring of Pearls appearance
Rokitansky nodule
Snowstorm appearance
Waterlily sign

questions.text: Identify the ultrasound finding:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Snowstorm appearance

  • The mass is composed of numerous anechoic cystic spaces of different sizes and shapes, but without a fetus or amniotic sac.
  • The appearance is often described as a “snowstorm” .
  • Application of color Doppler displays marked surrounding myometrial vascularity. However, absent internal flow reflects the avascular villi of complete moles.

Educational Objective: 

This image shows the typical snowstorm appearance seen on ultrasound in complete molar pregnancy

 

Ref: Williams textbook of obstetrics, 26 edition, chapter 13.

hCG

questions.text: Which of the following marker is likely to be raised in molar pregnancy:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. hCG

hCG is a critical marker for GTD.

 

 Ref : Berek and novak, 16th edition: page 2757

choices.text: Decreased
Increased
Unchanged
Can be increased or decreased depending upon complete/ partial mole

questions.text: You are posted in a gynecology ward and sending investigations for a woman with molar pregnancy. Her hCG level is >1,00,000. Her TSH levels are likely to be:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Decreased

Hyperthyroidism was observed in 7% patients with complete mole. Elevated free T3, T4 levels are found.

With increased T3, T4 levels, TSH is likely to be decreased.

 

Ref : Berek and novak 16 edition, page 2767

choices.text: Fluid overload
Metastatic disease suggestive of GTN
Thyroid storm
Trophoblastic embolization

questions.text: A woman with molar pregnancy is undergoing suction evacuation. Suddenly she develops breathing difficulty, tachypnoea and falls in saturation. The most likely cause is:
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Trophoblastic embolization

Trophoblastic Embolization

Respiratory distress rarely occurs in patients with a complete mole. It is usually diagnosed in patients with excessive uterine size and markedly elevated hG levels. These patients may have chest pain, dyspnea, tachypnea, and tachycardia and may experience severe respiratory distress during and after molar evacuation. Auscultation of the chest usually reveals diffuse rays, and chest radiographic evaluation may show bilateral pulmonary infiltrates. Respiratory distress usually resolves within 72 hours with cardiopulmonary support. In some circumstances, patients may require mechanical ventilation

 

Ref: Berek and novak, 16th edition. 2767

choices.text: Curette
Karman cannula
Manual vacuum aspiration syringe
Pipelle suction curette

questions.text: Identify the instrument:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Karman cannula

Suction curettage Within a few minutes of commencing suction curettage, the uterine size may decrease dramatically, and the bleeding will be well controlled. The use of a 12-mm cannula is strongly advised to facilitate evacuation. If the uterus is larger than 14 weeks of gestation, one hand should be placed on top of the fundus, and the uterus should be massaged to stimulate uterine contraction and reduce the risk of perforation.

Sharp curettage is done when suction evacuation is believed to be complete, gentle sharp curettage is performed to remove any residual molar tissue.

 

Ref: berek and novak, 16th edition, page 2770

choices.text: Barrier methods
Copper T
Injection DMPA
Oral contraceptive pills

questions.text: You are counseling a patient regarding management of molar pregnancy. Which of the following contraceptives is contraindicated in patients after evacuation for molar pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Copper T

Patients are encouraged to use effective contraception during the entire interval of hG follow-up. Because of the potential risk of uterine perforation, bleeding, and infection, intrauterine devices should not be inserted until the patient achieves a normal hG level. If the patient does not desire surgical sterilization, either oral contraceptives or barrier methods should be used.

 

Ref: berek and novak, 16th edition, page 2772

questions.text: As per the WHO, abortion is defined as pregnancy loss or termination before:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 20 weeks

  • The WHO and the CDC define abortion as pregnancy loss or termination before 20 weeks or with a fetus < 500 g
  • These criteria are contradictory as at 20 weeks, average fetal weight is 320 g

 

Ref: William’s Obstetrics 25th edition; page no 346

questions.text: Which part of the fallopian tube is the most common site of ectopic pregnancy?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. C

Explanation: (Ref: Page 371, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition)

  • Most common site for ectopic pregnancy is the fallopian tube
  • In the fallopian tube the most common site is: Ampulla
  • Ampulla > Isthmus > Infundibulum > Interstitial

questions.text: Risk of an ectopic pregnancy is highest with
questions.solution:
Ans: B. History of tunal surgery

Risk Factors

    • h/o Tubal Surgery (e.g., for fertility restoration or sterilization): HIGHEST RISK
    • Prior h/o salpingitis: 6 – 10-fold increased risk
    • h/o previous ectopic: 5-fold risk (10 – 15% chance of repeat ectopic)
    • Peri tubal adhesions (like endometriosis)
    • Salpingitis isthmica nodosa
    • Congenital tubal anomalies
    • Infertility (ART)
      • Associated with Atypical implantations and heterotopic pregnancies
    • Contraception: Relative numbers increased with intra-uterine devices (Absolute numbers decreased)

 

(Ref: Page 371, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition)

choices.text: Pain, bleeding, pallor
Pain, delayed menstruation, pallor
Bleeding, pain, delayed menstruation
Pallor, pain, delayed menstruation

questions.text: The classic triad of clinical features in an ectopic pregnancy is:
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Bleeding, pain, delayed menstruation

  • Clinical Features of an ectopic pregnancy vary but is typically characterized by the classic triad of
  1. Delayed menstruation
  2. Abdominal pain
  3. Vaginal Bleeding
  • Other symptoms may include:
  1. Passage of a decidual cast
  2. Severe hemoperitoneum: diaphragmatic irritation – shoulder pain
  3. Pallor, Shock – uterine rupture
  4. Abdominal tenderness
  5. Bimanual exam: cervical motion tenderness
  6. Tender boggy mass in the post fornix (collected blood)
  7. Cullen’s sign: Periumbilical bluish discoloration due to intraperitoneal bleeding

choices.text: Eccentrically located
Irregular
Yolk sac not seen
Intra-decidual sign not seen

questions.text: Which is incorrect regarding a pseudo sac?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Eccentrically located

 

Explanation:

  • A pseudo sac is seen in ectopic pregnancies. It is intrauterine fluid collection which gives the appearance of an intra-uterine gestational sac.

choices.text:
1.  

Bagel sign
Blob sign
Lemon sign
Tubal ring

questions.text: All are ultrasound signs of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Lemon sign

In Suspected unruptured ectopic pregnancy: Trans-vaginal Sonography (TVS) will reveal

    • An absent intra-uterine pregnancy
    • The presence of a pseudo-sac in the uterine cavity
    • The presence of an adnexal mass separate from the ovary
      • Hyperechoic ring surrounding an anechoic sac- seen in 20% (bagel sign/tubal ring sign)
      • Inhomogeneous mass – 60% (blob sign)
      • Obvious gestational sac with a fetal pole – 13%
    • On color doppler: “Ring of fire” seen. (D/d – Corpus luteal cyst)

 

*Lemon sign is seen in a fetus with spina bifida

 

Ref: page no 375, William Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Patient hemodynamically stable
Gestational sac size < 3.5 cm
Visible cardiac activity
Serum βhCG < 5000 IU/L

questions.text: All are indications for medical management of an unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Visible cardiac activity

Medical Management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy:

Indications: An unruptured ectopic pregnancy with:

      1. Patient hemodynamically stable
      2. No significant symptoms
      3. Gestational sac size < 3.5 cm
      4. No visible cardiac activity
      5. Serum βhCG < 5000 IU/L
      6. No contraindication to Methotrexate (Anemia, liver disease, bleeding disorder, active pulmonary disease etc.)

 

Ref: Page no 377, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 500 IU/L
1500 IU/L
2500 IU/L
3500 IU/L

questions.text: The value of βhCG above which an intra-uterine gestational sac should be seen is:
questions.solution:
Ans: B. 1500 IU/L

Discriminatory Zone: This is the level of serum βhCG above which an intra uterine gestational sac should be seen,

    • 1500 – 2000 IU/L for TVS
    • 5000 – 6000 IU/L for TAS

 

Ref: page no 373, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Complete abortion
Ectopic pregnancy
Pregnancy of undetermined location
Pseudocyesis

questions.text: A 33-year woman comes to the OPD with amenorrhea of 6 weeks. Her urine pregnancy test is positive. A transvaginal ultrasound is done which shows normal uterus and adnexa. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Pregnancy of undetermined location

 

Definition of Pregnancy of Undetermined Location (PUL):

 

  • A positive pregnancy test (urine or serum β-hCG)
  • No evidence of pregnancy in the uterus or adnexa on transvaginal ultrasound
  • This term is descriptive, not diagnostic—it requires follow-up to determine whether the pregnancy is:
    • Early intrauterine pregnancy
    • Ectopic pregnancy
    • Complete abortion
    • Biochemical pregnancy

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Complete abortion:

 

  • Would typically show an empty uterus after a previously confirmed intrauterine pregnancy
  • This patient has no prior ultrasound documentation of an intrauterine pregnancy

 

Option B. Ectopic pregnancy:

 

  • A definitive ectopic pregnancy should show adnexal mass or extrauterine gestational sac on TVUS
  • Here, adnexa are normal — no ectopic seen

 

Option D. Pseudocyesis:

 

  • A rare psychiatric condition where the patient falsely believes she is pregnant
  • Here, the pregnancy test is positive, which rules out pseudocyesis

 

 

Ref: page no 373, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: A failing intrauterine pregnancy
A Hydatiform mole
A recent complete abortion
An ectopic pregnancy

questions.text: A 20y G2A1 presents at 6 weeks pregnancy with vaginal bleeding. On TVS, no gestational sac is visualized. Her serum βhCG is 2000 IU/L. Which is NOT a possible diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. A Hydatiform mole

  • Discriminatory Zone: This is the level of serum βhCG above which an intra uterine gestational sac should be seen,
    • 1500 – 2000 IU/L for TVS
    • 5000 – 6000 IU/L for TAS
  • So, if serum βhCG levels are more than the discriminatory zone and still an intrauterine gestational sac is not seen on ultrasound, it is called a pregnancy of undetermined location & the following should be suspected:
    • Ectopic pregnancy
    • Failing intrauterine pregnancy
    • Recent complete abortion
    • Early multifetal pregnancy
  • In molar pregnancy, the βhCG levels are very high (usually > 100,000)

 

Ref: page no 374, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Mild abdominal pain
Gestational sac size < 3.5 cm with no cardiac activity
Clinically stable
βhCG < 1000 IU/L

questions.text: All are indications for expectant management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Mild abdominal pain

Expectant Management: This means no active intervention; just following up the patient with βhCG levels.

  • Only for clinically stable asymptomatic women with an ultrasound diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy with the following features
      1. Clinically stable with No pain AND
      2. Serum βhCG < 1000 IU/L AND
      3. Tubal ectopic < 35mm with no visible heartbeat AND
      4. Able to return for follow up
    2. Repeat βhCG levels on days 2, 4 and 7 after the original test
    3. If βhCG levels drop ≥ 15% from the previous values, then repeat weekly till a negative result
    4. If values fall < 15%, stay the same or rise from the previous value, review the condition and consider shifting to medical/ surgical management

 

Ref: page no 378, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition, https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng126

Mifepristone
Misoprostol

questions.text: The drug of choice for medical management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy is?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Methotrexate

  • The drug of choice for treatment of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy is Methotrexate.
  • MOA: Inhibits dihydrofolate reductase
  • 2 protocols: Single dose and Multidose
  • Usually, the single dose regime is sufficient, very rarely another dose is required.
  • 2 regimes:

 

Ref: Page no 377, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

Cervical pregnancy
Cornual pregnancy

questions.text: Rubin criteria is for
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Cervical pregnancy

  • Rubin criteria – Cervical pregnancy
  • Spiegelberg criteria – Ovarian pregnancy
  • Studdiford criteria – Primary abdominal pregnancy

 

Ref: Page no 383, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Interstitial tubal pregnancies rupture at very early gestational ages of 6-8 weeks
Both single dose and multi dose methotrexate are acceptable regimes for medical management
If single dose methotrexate is given, serum βhCG is checked on days 4 and 7
A woman who has had a previous ectopic pregnancy has a 5-fold increased risk of a repeat ectopic pregnancy

questions.text: All are true regarding unruptured tubal pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Interstitial tubal pregnancies rupture at very early gestational ages of 6-8 weeks

  • Ectopic pregnancy in the isthmic region rupture earliest (6 weeks)
  • Ectopic pregnancy in the interstitial area rupture at 12 – 16 weeks as they can grow into the uterine portion

 

Ref: Page no 132, Textbook of Obstetrics, JB Sharma

choices.text: Absent fetal erythrocytes
Diffuse trophoblastic proliferation
Marked trophoblastic atypia
Positive P57KIP2 immunostaining

questions.text: All are seen in complete mole except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Positive P57KIP2 immunostaining

p57 kip 2 staining is a feature seen when there is maternal tissue. As in a complete mole, there is no maternal component at all, there is negative p57kip 2 staining

Other Options

  • Option A: Absent fetal erythrocytes: This is a feature of complete mole. In conplete mole there is no fetal erythrocytes and there is no fetal aprts seen
  • Option B: Diffuse trophoblastic proliferation: This is also a feature of complete mole
  • Option C: Marked trophoblastic atypia: This is also a feature of complete mole.m

Educational Objective: 

Remember P57KIP2 is an IHC marker that is maternally expressed and hence absent in complete mole which has no maternal component.

 

Ref: page no. 389, William’s Obstetrics, 25th edition

choices.text: Treatment is by suction evacuation
A baseline hemogram, TSH and Chest X-Ray is essential
Evacuation under ultrasound guidance is preferable
Inj. Anti-D in Rh negative women is not required

questions.text: All are true regarding treatment of molar pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Inj. Anti-D in Rh negative women is not required

Let's Discuss all the Options

  • Option A: Treatment of molar pregnancy is by suction evacuation is a correct statement
  • Option B: A baseline hemogram, TSH and Chest X-Ray is essential is also correct
  • Option C: Evacuation under ultrasound guidance is preferable is also correct as we know whether all products have been evacuated or not. 
  • Option D: Inj Anti-D in Rh negative women followinsuction evacuation in mplar pregnancy IS REQUIRED to prevent Anti D Antibody formation in Rh negative pregnancies

Educational Objective: 

Important points to note during suction evacuation of molar pregnancy:

  • Pre-operative Care
    • Investigations
      • Hemogram
      • Baseline serum β-hCG
      • TSH
      • Blood group & Rh
      • Chest X-Ray
  • Intra-op Points to note
    • Large bore IV Cannula as blood loss is anticipated
    • Oxytocin 20 U in 1 L RL – continuous infusion; preferably start at the start of suction
    • Use uterotonic agents (methergine, misoprostol, carboprost)
    • Use a larger Karman’s cannula size (size 10-14)
    • Under USG guidance
    • Gentle curette with blunt end
  • Post operative Points to note
    • Anti-D given after procedure
    • Initiate effective contraception
    • Review histopathology report
    • Serum β-hCG within 48 h of evacuation; then weekly till undetectable.

 

Reference: Page no. 392, William’s Obstetrics, 25th edition

choices.text: The risk of progression to Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia is same for both complete and partial moles
The risk of progression to Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia is higher with partial mole
The risk of progression to Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia is higher with complete mole
There is no risk of progression to Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia following evacuation of either partial or complete mole.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding Hydatidiform mole is true?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. The risk of progression to gestational trophoblastic neoplasia is higher with complete mole.

Let's Discuss all the Options:

Option A: The risk of progression to Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia is same for both complete and partial moles: This is an incorrect statment as the risk is more with complete mole

Option B: The risk of progression to Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia is higher with partial mole: This is also wrong as the risk is higher with a complete mole

Option C: The risk of progression to gestational trophoblastic neoplasia is higher with comple(!5-20%) compared with a partial mole (1-5%)

Option D: There is no risk of progression to Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia following evacuation of either partial or complete mole. This is also wrong. There is a definite increased risk of choriocarcinoma with both partial and complete mole. 

Educational Objective: 

 

  • Risk of progress of complete mole to GTN: 15-20 %
  • Risk of progress of partial mole to GTN: 1-5%

 

Ref: Page 393, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Hypothyroidism
Diabetes mellitus
Hyperthyroidism
Hyperprolactinemia

questions.text: Which of the following is associated with Hydatidiform mole?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Hyperthyroidism

Hyperthyroidism is associated with molar pregnancy as: 

  • The alpha subunit of hCG is similar to TSH
  • So the increased hCG stimulates more thyroxine production which in turn has a negative feedback on TSH so TSH levels reduce.
  • Complete mole is more often associated with hyperthyroidism than partial mole

Educational Objective: 

Hyperthyroidism is associated with molar pregnancy 

Ref: Page no 390, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text:
1.  

Conservative
Medical management
Suction and evacuation
Follow-up with β-hCG for next 2 weeks

questions.text: Lady came with intractable vomiting. USG shows snowstorm appearances for 6 weeks. Next step in management?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Suction & evacuation.

  • Snowstorm appearance is the characteristic appearance of a complete mole.
  • Treatment of molar pregnancy is suction-evacuation

Other Options: 

1. Conservative management: Is not indicated as this is a molar pregnancy and conservative maangement has no role

2. Medical management: There is no role of medical management in molar pregnancy

3. Follow-up with β-hCG for next 2 weeks:  Beta hCG is done after evacuation for surveillance because of the risk of choriocarcinoma

Educational Objective:

  • Snowstorm appearance is the characteristic appearance of a complete mole.
  • Treatment of molar pregnancy is suction-evacuation followed by beta hCG surveillance

 

Ref: page 392, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Choriocarcinoma
Placental site trophoblastic tumor
Partial mole
Invasive mole

questions.text: Which of the following is not included in gestational trophoblastic neoplasm?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Partial mole

Partial mole is NOT a type of gestational trophablastic neoplasia

All the other options: Choriocarcinoma, Placental site trophoblastic tumor and invasive mole are types of gestational trophoblastic neplasias

Educational Objective: 

Gestational Trophoblastic Disease (GTD): Includes all abnormal trophoblastic proliferation pathologies. Classified as:

  1. Hydatidiform Mole
    1. Complete mole
    2. Partial mole
    3. Invasive mole
  2. Non molar trophoblastic
    1. Choriocarcinoma
    2. Placental site trophoblastic disease
    3. Epithelioid trophoblastic tumor
  • Gestational Trophoblastic Neoplasia (GTN): Includes all the malignancies i.e.
  1. Invasive mole
  2. Choriocarcinoma
  3. Placental site trophoblastic disease
  4. Epithelioid trophoblastic tumor  
  • Hence both partial and complete mole do not come under GTN as they are not malignant

 

Ref: page no 388, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 46 XX
46 XY
69 XXX
45 XO

questions.text: Which of the following represents the correct karyotype of a partial mole?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 69XXX

Remember: Partial moles are always TRIPLOID

Educational Objective: 

  • Partial moles are always TRIPLOID (69XXX/ 69 XXY)
    • 2 sperm fertilize one ova
    • The paternal contribution is called diandry
    • Hence both maternal and paternal component present in partial mole
    • Usually, 69XXX or 69XXY
  • Complete moles are DIPLOID
    • Formed by either 1 sperm fertilizing an empty/ inactivated ova and then undergoes duplication – this is called androgenesis

OR

  • 2 sperms (dispermy) fertilize an empty/ inactivated ovum
  • 46XX or 46 XY
  • Only paternal component
  • No maternal component

 

Ref: page no 389 Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Complete abortion
Ectopic pregnancy
Incomplete abortion
Molar pregnancy

questions.text: A 20 year old woman presents to emergency with 3 months amenorrhea and passage of vesicles as shown in image.
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Molar pregnancy

This is an image showing the grape like vesicles of a complete molar pregnancy

 

Educational Objective:

Ref : Williams obstetrics, 26th edition, chapter 13

choices.text: Clinical history of passage of clear vesicles
Histological features showing hydropic changes in villi/ trophoblastic proliferation
Increased beta hCG levels
Ultrasound feature of snowstorm appearance

questions.text: A woman presents to emergency with amenorrhea, bleeding and passage of clear vesicles. She undergoes suction evacuation. The definitive diagnosis of molar pregnancy is made by:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Histological features showing hydropic changes in villi/ trophoblastic proliferation

The definitive diagnosis of a molar pregnancy is made by histological examination.

  • Pathological features consistent with the diagnosis of complete molar pregnancies include
    • Absence of fetal tissue
    • Extensive hydropic change to the villi
    • Excess trophoblast proliferation.
  • Features of a partial molar pregnancy include:
    • Presence of fetal tissue
    • Focal hydropic change to the villi
    • Focal trophoblast proliferation.

Ploidy status and immunohistochemistry staining for p57, a paternally imprinted gene, may help in distinguishing partial from complete molar pregnancies (it is positive in partial moles)

Educational Objective: 

  • Pathological features consistent with the diagnosis of complete molar pregnancies include
    • Absence of fetal tissue
    • Extensive hydropic change to the villi
    • Excess trophoblast proliferation.
  • Features of a partial molar pregnancy include:
    • Presence of fetal tissue
    • Focal hydropic change to the villi
    • Focal trophoblast proliferation.

Ref: Management of Gestational Trophoblastic Disease

Green-top Guideline No. 38 – June 2020

choices.text: Complete abortion
Complete mole
Incomplete abortion
Partial mole

questions.text:
A 19 year old primigravida presents to OPD with amenorrhea of 2.5 months, positive urine pregnancy test and bleeding per vagina. Her ultrasound image shown below.

She is most likely a case of?
questions.solution:
This is a complete mole as seen by the typical snowstorm appearance in the image

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Complete abortion: An empty uterine cavity will be seen
  • Option C: Incomplete abortion: Retained products of conception will be seen
  • Option D: Partial mole: This may resemble a missed abortion, an irregular gestational sac may be seen, even fetal parts may be seen

Educational Objective:

This is the typical ultrasound "snowstorm" appearance seen in complete molar pregnancy

 

 

 

 

Ref : Williams obstetrics, 26th edition, chapter 13

choices.text: Parvovirus infection
Partial mole
Rh incompatibility
Smoking in pregnancy

questions.text:
A patient visits for ultrasound at 18 weeks, which shows fetus with syndactyly with multicystic placenta as shown below.

The most likely cause is:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Partial mole

When a fetus is present in conjunction with a partial mole, it may have fetal parts, an irregular gestational sac, a multicystic placenta  or a fetus exhibiting the stigmata of triploidy such as growth retardation, syndactyly and hydrocephaly.

Other Options: 

  • Option A: Parvivirus infection will present with fetal hydrops 
  • Option C: Rh incompatibility will present with fetal hydrops if there is iso-immunization
  • Option D: Smoking in pregnancy: Smoking is associated with placenta previa, abruption and fetal growth restriciton

Educational Objective: 

The first image below shows the snowstorm appearance on ultrasound seen in a complete molw

The second image shows the features of a partial mole (fetal parts seen, multicystic placenta, fetus with syndactyly, hydrocephaly and growth retardation can be seen)

    

 

Ref : Berek and novak, 16th edition, page 2762

Williams obstetrics, 26th edition, chapter 13

choices.text: 46XX, of maternal and paternal origin
46XX, of paternal origin only
69 XXY, of maternal and paternal origin
69 XXY, of paternal origin only

questions.text: A 20 year old woman undergoes suction evacuation for molar pregnancy. Histopathology features are suggestive of complete mole. Regarding karyotype of the tissue, which of the following is most likely:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 46XX, of paternal origin only

Complete mole: The molar chromosomes are entirely of paternal origin. They usually have a 46XX karyotype, about 10% have 46 XY karyotype.

Other Options: 

  • Option A: 46XX, of maternal and paternal origin: This is incorrect as complete moles contain only paternal component
  • Option C: 69 XXY, of maternal and paternal origin: This is incoorect as complete moles are diploid and contain only paternal component
  • Option D: 69 XXY, of paternal origin only: This is incorrect as complete moles are diploid and not triploid

Educational Objective: 

In Complete mole, The molar chromosomes are entirely of paternal origin. They usually have a 46XX karyotype, about 10% have 46 XY karyotype.

Ref: Berek and novak, 16th edition, page 2760

choices.text: 46XX
46 XY
69XXX
69YYY

questions.text: A 21 year old woman presented to emergency with 3 months pregnancy and bleeding per vaginum. She underwent suction evacuation for suspected molar pregnancy. Histopathology confirmed the diagnosis and showed scalloping of chorionic villi. The karyotype is likely to be
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 69 XXX

Scalloping of chorionic villi is suggestive of partial mole. Partial moles have triploid karyotype. Of the given triploid options, 69 YYY is non viable gamete.

 

Ref: Berek and novak 16 edition page 2764

choices.text: Chemotherapy
Hysterotomy
Suction evacuation
Uterine artery embolization

questions.text: A woman presents to the emergency ward with 5 months of amenorrhea and bleeding PV, her fundal height is 18 weeks, but external ballotment is absent. USG showed a snowstorm appearance. What is the best management option for her:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Suction evacuation

Suction curettage is the preferred method of evacuation, irrespective of the uterine size.

 

Ref: Berek and novak, 16th edition: page 2770

QUESTION LEVEL-INTERMEDIATE

choices.text: Absent in complete mole as it is maternal in origin
Absent in complete mole as it is paternal in origin
Present in complete mole as it is maternal in origin
Present in complete mole as it is paternal in origin

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true in relation to P57 immunostaining in molar pregnancy:
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Absent in complete mole as it is paternal in origin

p57KIP2 is a nuclear protein whose gene is paternally imprinted and maternally expressed. This means that the gene product is produced only in tissues containing a maternal allele. Because complete moles contain only paternal genes, the p57KIP2 protein is absent in complete moles, and tissues do not pick up this stain.

 

Ref: Williams obstetrics 26th edition, chapter 13.

choices.text: no further follow up required
till One more negative value 1 month later
Monthly follow up for 6 months
Monthly follow up for 1 year

questions.text: A woman underwent suction evacuation for a complete mole. She was on weekly hCG follow up which has now returned to normal. What will be your advice to her for further follow up:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Monthly follow up for 6 months

Follow-up hCG monitoring every 1–2 weeks is essential for early diagnosis of and management of postmolar GTN.  Postmolar GTN rarely occurs after the spontaneous return of hCG levels to normal, allowing for a shortened follow-up period for most women.

Hence, a single additional confirmatory normal hCG measurement 1 month after first hCG normalization is recommended for a partial mole and monthly hCG measurements should be obtained for only 6 months after hCG normalization for a Complete mole.

choices.text: Choriocarcinoma
Epithelioid trophoblastic tumor (ETT)
Molar pregnancy
Placental site trophoblastic tumor (PSTT)

questions.text: Gestational trophoblastic neoplasia includes all Except:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Molar pregnancy

 

Gestational trophoblastic disease (GTD) is a group of uncommon conditions associated with pregnancy. Histologically, it includes the premalignant partial hydatidiform mole (PHM) and complete hydatidiform mole (CHM), as well as the malignant invasive mole, choriocarcinoma, placental site trophoblastic tumor (PSTT), and epithelioid trophoblastic tumor (ETT). The last three malignant forms can arise after any type of pregnancy and all are collectively known as gestational trophoblastic neoplasia (GTN). The GTD spectrum has recently been expanded to also include atypical placental site nodule (APSN) as 10%–15% may coexist with or develop into PSTT/ETT

 

 

Ref: FIGO cancer report 2021

choices.text: Endometriosis
History of salpingitis
Previous ectopic pregnancy
Previous cesarean

questions.text: All are risk factors for tubal ectopic pregnancy except?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Previous cesarean 

Risk Factors

    • h/o Tubal Surgery (e.g., for fertility restoration or sterilization): As per Williams Obstetrics 25th edition (page 371): HIGHEST RISK
    • Prior h/o salpingitis: 6 – 10-fold increased risk
    • h/o previous ectopic: 5-fold risk (10 – 15% chance of repeat ectopic)
    • Peri tubal adhesions (like endometriosis)
    • Salpingitis isthmica nodosa
    • Congenital tubal anomalies
    • Infertility (artificial Reproductive techniques like IVF)
      • Associated with Atypical implantations and heterotopic pregnancies
    • Contraception: Relative numbers increased with intra-uterine devices (Absolute numbers decreased)
      • Intra uterine devices
      • Progesterone only pill

Ref: Page 371, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Dilatation and evacuation
Shift to the O.T. for an emergency laparotomy
Urgent serum βhCG
Urgent ultrasound

questions.text: A 24y lady presented to the emergency with  generalized pain and spotting PV. Her LMP was 2 months back and she has a history of irregular cycles. On examination, she is pale, her PR is 110/ min, BP is 80/60 mmHg. There is guarding and rigidity on abdominal examination and a vaginal exam reveals cervical motion tenderness. Her urine pregnancy test is weakly positive. What is the next best step?
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Shift to the O.T. for an emergency laparotomy

This is  most likely a ruptured ectopic pregnancy,

D/d of bleeding in the 1st trimester

  •  
    1.  

      1. Implantation bleeding (Placental Sign)

      2. Abortion (threatened, inevitable, incomplete, complete, missed)

      3. Ectopic Pregnancy

      4. Molar pregnancy

  • Classic triad of symptoms I.e., pain, bleeding and delayed menstruation is seen in an ectopic pregnancy.

  • In this scenario there is pain and bleeding with a positive pregnancy test and on examination there is pallor, shock and intraperitoneal bleed which points to a ruptured ectopic pregnancy.

  • Next best management option is immediate surgical management i.e., laparotomy

  • Doing an ultrasound will cause a delay and worsen patient prognosis

  • Beta hCG is not indicated in a ruptured ectopic. It only has a role in an unruptured ectopic.

 

Ref: Page 371, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: 2,3,4,1
2,3,1,4
3,2,1,4
3,2,4,1

questions.text:
Arrange the following ectopic sites in decreasing order of occurrence

  1. Interstitial
  2. Isthmus
  3. Ampulla
  4. Infundibulum
questions.solution:
Ans: D. 3,2,4,1

  • The most common site for ectopic pregnancy: Fallopian tube
  • In the fallopian tube; the most common site is: Ampulla
  • Ampulla > Isthmus > Infundibulum > Interstitial

 

Ref: Page 371, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

Question Id:

choices.text: Corpus luteal cyst, Circle of fire sign
Corpus luteal cyst, Ring of fire sign.
Unruptured ectopic pregnancy, Circle of fire sign
Unruptured ectopic pregnancy, Ring of fire sign

questions.text: A 30-year lady presented to the gyn OPD with complaints of mild abdominal pain and spotting. She gives a history of delayed menses by about 7 days. Her UPT is faintly positive. An ultrasound with color doppler reveals the following image. What is the diagnosis and what is this sign known as?
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Unruptured ectopic pregnancy, Ring of fire sign

  • The patient’s history is suggestive of an ectopic pregnancy (classic triad of pain, bleeding and delayed menstruation is there)
  • The image shows the classical “ring of fire” sign which is peri-trophoblastic vascularity.
  • This flow on doppler can also be seen in a corpus luteal cyst.

 

Ref: page no 376, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: The level above which an ectopic gestational sac should be visualized
The level below which an ectopic gestational sac should be visualized
The level above which an intra-uterine gestational sac should be visualized
The level below which an intra-uterine gestational sac should be visualized

questions.text: What is the discriminatory zone for βhCG?
questions.solution:
Ans: C. The level above which an intra-uterine gestational sac should be visualized

  • Discriminatory Zone: This is the level of serum βhCG above which an intra uterine gestational sac should be seen,
      •  1500 – 2000 IU/L for TVS
      • 5000 – 6000 IU/L for TAS

 

  • There is another concept of hCG called as doubling time. This means that βhCG levels should double every 48h in early pregnancy in a normal intra-uterine pregnancy. Actually doubling is a misnomer. The rise in βhCG should be >60% at least in 48h.

 

Ref: page no 373, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Expectant management
Single dose inj Methotrexate
Laparoscopic salpingostomy
Laparoscopic salpingotomy

questions.text: A 34-year woman presents to the gyn OPD with an unruptured tubal ectopic pregnancy. She has no symptoms and is hemodynamically stable. Her βhCG is 600 IU/L. The ultrasound shows a gestational sac measuring 20 mm in the right adnexa with no yolk sac or embryo seen. Which of these is the most appropriate management?
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Expectant management

Expectant Management

  • Only for clinically stable asymptomatic women with an ultrasound diagnosis of ectopic pregnancy with the following features
      1. Clinically stable with No pain AND
      2. Serum βhCG < 1000 IU/L AND
      3. Tubal ectopic < 35mm with no visible heartbeat AND
      4. Able to return for follow up
  • Repeat βhCG levels on days 2, 4 and 7 after the original test
  • If βhCG levels drop ≥ 15% from the previous values, then repeat weekly till a negative result
  • If values fall < 15%, stay the same or rise from the previous value, review the condition and consider shifting to medical/ surgical management

 

Ref: page no 378, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition, https://www.nice.org.uk/guidance/ng126

choices.text: Endometrial biopsy
Cervical biopsy
Culdocentesis
Pap smear

questions.text: Identify this procedure:
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Culdocentesis

  • In the absence of TVS and if the diagnosis of a ruptured ectopic is still in doubt: Culdocentesis can be done:
      1. Simple technique
      2. Cervix pulled outward and upward (holding a tenaculum/ vulsullum) on the posterior cervix.
      3. 18-gauge needle is inserted in the posterior fornix
      4. Aspiration of non-clotting blood signifies hemoperitoneum
      5. A negative Culdocentesis does not rule out a ruptured ectopic pregnancy

   

 

Ref: page no 376, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Laparoscopic salpingectomy
Laparoscopic salpingostomy
Inj Methotrexate single dose
Inj methotrexate multiple doses

questions.text: A 34y old lady with a history of a tubal sterilization is diagnosed to have an unruptured ectopic pregnancy of size 4 cm. Serum βhCG is 6000 IU/L. The preferred management option is:
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Laparoscopic salpingectomy

 

This woman is not a candidate for medical management as the size is > 3.5 cm and βhCG is > 3000 IU/L..

 

  • She requires surgical management: In an unruptured ectopic: Laparoscopy is preferred

    1. SALPINGECTOMY: Preferred if:

      • Extensive tubal involvement/ damage

      • Recurrent ectopic pregnancy in the same tube

      • Completed family

      • Ectopic at the site of a previous tubal sterilization

    2. SALPINGOSTOMY: (Linear incision on the antimesenteric border with removal of products of conception)

      • Consider if a woman has other infertility factors also OR has a contralateral damaged/removed tube and wants to conceive in the future

 

Ref: page no 379, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Salpingectomy
Salpingostomy
Tubal recanalization
Tubal sterilization

questions.text: Identify this procedure:
questions.solution:
Ans: B. Salpingostomy

  • The procedure shown is a laparoscopic salpingostomy
  • It is done in an unruptured ectopic where the fallopian tube needs to be conserved

 

Ref: Page 176, JC Dutta Textbook of Obstetrics 9th edition

choices.text: ​​​Abdominal pregnancy
Cervical pregnancy
Cornual pregnancy
Ovarian pregnancy

questions.text: Spiegelberg criteria is for:
questions.solution:
Ans: D. Ovarian pregnancy

Rubin criteria – Cervical pregnancy

  • Spiegelberg criteria – Ovarian pregnancy
  • Studdiford criteria – Primary abdominal pregnancy

 

Ref: Page no 383, Williams Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text:
1.  

< 5000 IU/L
< 6000 IU/L
< 7000 IU/L
< 10000 IU/L

questions.text: Medical management of an unruptured ectopic pregnancy is recommended when the serum βhCG is
questions.solution:
Ans: A. < 5000 IU/L

  • Indications for medical management of unruptured ectopic pregnancy:
  1. Patient hemodynamically stable
  2. No significant symptoms
  3. Gestational sac size < 3.5 cm
  4. No visible cardiac activity
  5. Serum βhCG < 5000 IU/L
  6. No contraindication to Methotrexate (Anemia, liver disease, bleeding disorder, active pulmonary disease etc.)
  • Failure rate of medical management is about 4% if βhCG < 5000 IU/ but increases to 14% if βhCG is 10000 IU/L

 

Ref: Page no 377, William’s Obstetrics 25th edition

choices.text: Expectant
Medical
Surgical
Medical + Surgical

questions.text: The preferred treatment in heterotopic pregnancy is:
questions.solution:
Ans: C. Surgical

  • Incidence of heterotopic pregnancy: increasing due to ART
  • Treatment of choice: Surgical
  • Medical management with methotrexate is contra-indicated as it will kill the intrauterine pregnancy also

 

Ref: page no 142, Textbook of Obstetrics JB Sharma
